title: The Best & Worst Glute Exercises (According To Science)

S-Tier.execution_notes: Lean forward by about 30 degrees to improve the line of pull of the upper glute fibers and feel a deeper stretch at the bottom. Perform for 15 to 20 reps, though heavier low rep work is also effective. Progressively overload by increasing the pin weight. When the stack is maxed out, use a gym pin to add more weight. For extra range of motion, add an extra pad on the inside.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Fantastic for the upper glutes because they directly challenge the glute medius and minimus through their primary function of hip abduction. So good at targeting the upper glutes.
S-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Upper glutes, as the exercise directly targets the glute medius and minimus, which are located in the upper glute region and are primarily responsible for hip abduction.
S-Tier.limitations: May not be the best overall glute builder.
S-Tier.additional_notes: This is the number one exercise for the upper glutes.

S-Tier.execution_notes: Take longer strides forward and lean slightly forward by about 30 degrees to accentuate the glute stretch. Focus on moving through space.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Provides a massive glute stretch when taking big steps. The movement through space is motivating. Causes significant soreness, which, while not everything, indicates strong muscle engagement.
S-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Entire glute. Upper glutes are activated due to glute medius engagement from stabilization demands. Mid glutes are targeted through hip extension. Lower glute area benefits from the deep stretch.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Bulgarian split squats can provide a slightly better stretch.
S-Tier.additional_notes: This is considered the 'best of the best' (S+ tier) exercise. The presenter is a huge fan.

S-Tier.setup_notes: Elevate your front foot on a small box.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: Elevating the front foot provides a bit more range of motion at the bottom, enhancing the glute stretch and engagement.
S-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Entire glute, with enhanced stretch in the lower glute area due to increased range of motion.

S-Tier.execution_notes: Extend your hips. Round your upper back to connect with your glutes much better. Overload by adding reps or holding plates to your chest.
S-Tier.tier_reasons: The entire glutes are very active in both the lengthened position at the bottom and the shortened position at the top due to hip extension. Very conducive to progressive overload.
S-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Entire glutes, as it trains hip extension, engaging the glutes throughout the full range of motion.
S-Tier.additional_notes: Often mistakenly thought of as just a low back exercise.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: The belt is much more comfortable than a barbell. No setup time is required. The machine is very stable, eliminating the need for balance and allowing for better focus on glute engagement.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Entire glute, but mainly targets the middle glutes by isolating hip extension.
A-Tier.limitations: Lack of a really deep stretch.
A-Tier.additional_notes: The presenter personally does these every single week. This is the number one option for the middle aspect of the glutes.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Stick to 12 to 15 reps and focus on controlling the movement. Avoid going heavy.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Helps prevent left-to-right muscle imbalances by allowing focus on each glute individually. The glute medius and minimus are engaged for balance, potentially shifting emphasis to the upper glutes.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Entire glutes, with a potential shift of emphasis to the upper glutes due to the stabilization demands on the glute medius and minimus.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Place the bar a few inches lower on your back.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Lean further forward and focus on driving through your hips to make the movement more glute dominant. Squat deeper, trying to at least break parallel.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: An underrated glute builder that activates all regions of the glutes, especially the middle chunk, by extending the hips.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: All regions of the glutes, but especially the middle chunk. The glutes are activated through hip extension.
A-Tier.limitations: Does not isolate the glutes well, providing a huge quad stimulus. If the goal is only glute growth without quad growth, this is not the best option.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: Research shows that squatting deeper is important for glute growth.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Most of the presenter's own glute development comes from squats due to his powerlifting background.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Place your feet further forward to make it more glute dominant.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Allows for a glute-dominant foot placement without worrying about losing balance, as the machine provides stability.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: All regions of the glutes, especially the middle chunk, with increased emphasis on the glutes due to foot placement.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Place your front foot further forward.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Lean forward as you squat and think about driving through your hips rather than just standing up with your knees to engage your glutes better. Perform two sets per leg.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Achieves a deeper stretch on the glutes than a standard barbell squat. As a single-leg exercise, it involves the upper glutes more due to the stability requirement, engaging the glute medius and minimus.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Middle glutes (from hip extension) and upper glutes (from stabilization demands). Provides a deep stretch on the entire glute.
A-Tier.limitations: Can be harder to overload, especially when using dumbbells. It heavily taxes the quads and is a generally exhausting movement.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Brace against the machine or a bench for stability.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Kick up and out diagonally to target the upper glutes, as upper glute fibers perform both hip extension (up) and hip abduction (out and diagonally).
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Very stable, especially when bracing against the machine or a bench. Offers a nice and smooth resistance profile. Great option for isolating the glutes without significantly engaging the quads.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Upper glutes, specifically targeting the upper glute fibers that perform hip extension and abduction.
A-Tier.limitations: Does not provide the biggest stretch.
A-Tier.additional_notes: The presenter does not do a lot of these personally but considers them a great option.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Set the box a little higher, at or just above knee level. If available, use a handle to grab onto for better balance.
A-Tier.execution_notes: Focus on engaging your glutes more than your quads. Using a handle can help overload the glutes even more.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Targets the upper glutes because it's a single-leg movement, and the stability requirement engages the glute medius and minimus. Provides a deep stretch on the entire glute, especially with a higher box, which forces the glutes to work harder than the quads.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Upper glutes (due to glute medius/minimus activation for stability) and the entire glute (due to deep stretch).
A-Tier.limitations: Can be a bit awkward at first until proper glute engagement is learned.
A-Tier.additional_notes: Considered 'killer' once the technique is mastered to engage glutes over quads.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: A basic compound lift that is very conducive to progressive overload. Smashes the gluteus maximus.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Lower glutes and the glute-hamstring tie-in area. While it hits the hamstrings hard, it is a better choice for glute hypertrophy.
A-Tier.additional_notes: This is the number one exercise for the lower glutes.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: Offers all the same benefits as walking lunges, such as targeting the entire glute, engaging upper glutes through stabilization, and providing a deep stretch.
A-Tier.limitations: The presenter has a personal preference against doing all reps on the spot when the option to move through space is available.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Use a big cushy pad or roll up some yoga mats to alleviate hip pinching. Strategically place the bar in the cushy crease of your hip, below the anterior superior iliac spine and above the pubic bone.
B-Tier.execution_notes: Perform in the 5 to 15 rep range, focusing on keeping your form tight.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Very effective at growing the glutes, activating the entire glute (upper, middle, and lower), mainly targeting the middle glutes by isolating hip extension. It is a great movement for progressive overload, allowing for consistent weight increases.
B-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Entire glute (upper, middle, and lower), but mainly targets the middle glutes due to its isolation of hip extension.
B-Tier.limitations: Many people find the barbell pinches their hips, even with padding, it can still feel awkward. It takes time to set up, especially without a dedicated hip thrust platform or when loading many plates. It doesn't get the glutes into a super deep stretch, reaching only about 90 degrees of hip flexion compared to the 130 degrees possible for most lifters.
B-Tier.scientific_insights: A recent 9-week study with untrained subjects found that the hip thrust was just as effective as the squat at growing the glutes, despite the squat providing a deeper stretch. Other research suggests glutes respond well to deeper training, implying optimal growth comes from a combination of exercises that challenge glutes in stretched (e.g., squat) and shortened (e.g., hip thrust) positions.
B-Tier.additional_notes: You don't need a 500lb hip thrust to grow your glutes; consistent strength gains in the 5-15 rep range indicate glute growth.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: Easier to set up than a hip thrust because it doesn't require a bench. Great for beginners as it requires less stabilization. Some individuals report better glute isolation by taking some of the quads out.
B-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Middle glutes, similar to a hip thrust but with less range of motion.
B-Tier.limitations: Offers less range of motion compared to the hip thrust.
B-Tier.alternative_options: It is essentially a hip thrust but with less range of motion.
B-Tier.additional_notes: The presenter still prefers the hip thrust due to its greater range of motion.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: Performs the same basic function as machine hip abductions, targeting the glute medius and minimus.
B-Tier.limitations: Harder to overload compared to machine hip abductions. Not as stable. More annoying to set up.
B-Tier.alternative_options: Performs the same basic movement as machine hip abductions.

B-Tier.execution_notes: Step back diagonally behind your other leg.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Activates the glute medius more due to the increased balance requirement, making it a good option for the upper glutes.
B-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Upper glutes, due to increased glute medius activation from the balance demands.
B-Tier.limitations: Harder to overload compared to a standard lunge. Not considered as effective as a standard lunge.
B-Tier.additional_notes: Can be included every now and then as an option.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: A good glute builder as it trains hip extension and provides a big stretch on the lower glutes. Excellent for progressive overload.
B-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Lower glutes, due to the big stretch provided.
B-Tier.limitations: It is a very fatiguing exercise, both physically and psychologically, leading to a low stimulus-to-fatigue ratio. It generates a lot of fatigue, especially in muscles other than the glutes, such as the spinal erectors.
B-Tier.additional_notes: While elite as a strength builder, it is not ideal for glute hypertrophy.

B-Tier.setup_notes: Use a wider stance and foot flare.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: The wider stance and foot flare, which involve hip abduction and hip external rotation, likely hit the glute medius harder and may shift some emphasis toward the upper glutes.
B-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Similar to conventional deadlift for gluteus maximus, but likely targets the upper glutes more due to increased glute medius activation.
B-Tier.alternative_options: Very similar to the conventional deadlift.
B-Tier.scientific_insights: An EMG study found no difference in gluteus maximus EMG activity between conventional and Sumo stances.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: Great for beginners who lack significant glute strength.
B-Tier.limitations: Eventually, the amount of weight that can be held comfortably becomes a limiting factor. The exercise starts to feel awkward once significant weight is used.

C-Tier.setup_notes: Externally rotate your hips and clamp your feet together.
C-Tier.tier_reasons: Shifts some emphasis to the upper glutes because abducting the hips engages the glute medius more.
C-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Upper glutes, due to hip abduction engaging the glute medius.
C-Tier.limitations: Hard to load, which forces the use of very high repetitions. Does not stretch the glutes very well.
C-Tier.alternative_options: Similar to a hip thrust, but with external hip rotation and clamped feet.
C-Tier.additional_notes: The presenter doesn't hate these as a high-rep finisher.

C-Tier.limitations: The band offers virtually zero tension in the stretched position.
C-Tier.alternative_options: Same basic movement pattern as hip abductions.
C-Tier.additional_notes: Fine as a warm-up drill or for helping beginners engage their glute medius, but will not add much muscle mass to the glutes unless the individual is a beginner.

D-Tier.tier_reasons: Very hard to overload, even with a resistance band. Provides very little tension while the glutes are stretched. Progressive overload is difficult to achieve using a band.
D-Tier.limitations: Hard to overload, very little tension at stretch, hard to progressively overload with a band.
D-Tier.additional_notes: Solid as a warm-up activation drill or to help beginners feel their glutes engage, but not effective as a glute hypertrophy exercise. Considered one of the 'worst of the worst' for muscle growth.

D-Tier.tier_reasons: Do not generate high tension on the glutes.
D-Tier.limitations: Do not get high tension on the glutes.
D-Tier.additional_notes: Can be useful for mobility or in rehabilitation contexts, but not as a glute builder for hypertrophy. Considered one of the 'worst of the worst' for muscle growth.

D-Tier.tier_reasons: Does not provide enough tension for glute hypertrophy.
D-Tier.limitations: Not enough tension for glute hypertrophy.
D-Tier.additional_notes: Can provide a good cardio workout and has some utility for building explosive power.

criterias.high_tension_stretched_position: The exercise needs to provide significant tension to the glutes, especially when the muscle is in a lengthened or stretched position.

criterias.feels_good: The exercise should be performed without causing pain in the knees, hips, or lower back.

criterias.progressive_overload: There must be a clear and consistent method to increase the resistance or difficulty of the exercise over time to ensure continuous muscle growth.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.gluteus_maximus: The largest and most powerful glute muscle, responsible for hip extension (like in a deadlift) and external rotation of the leg (pointing toes out). It's the powerhouse of the lower body.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.gluteus_medius: Approximately one-third the size of the gluteus maximus, with similar muscle mass to the deltoids. It sits on the upper glutes, contributing to the 'upper glute shelf' appearance. Its primary function is hip abduction (sweeping the leg out to the side), and it's a crucial stabilizer, especially active during single-leg exercises.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.gluteus_minimus: About half the size of the gluteus medius. It plays a key stabilization role and can contribute to the size of the upper glutes.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.upper_glutes: A division of the glutes that benefits from exercises involving hip abduction and stabilization.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.middle_glutes: A division of the glutes primarily targeted by hip extension movements.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.lower_glutes: A division of the glutes that responds well to exercises providing a deep stretch.

main_knowledge_summary.form_details: For **Barbell Hip Thrusts**, place the bar in the cushy crease of the hip, below the anterior superior iliac spine and above the pubic bone, using a large pad or rolled-up yoga mats to alleviate pinching. For **Squats**, position the bar a few inches lower on the back, lean further forward, and focus on driving through the hips, ensuring to squat at least parallel for glute growth. With **Smith Machine Squats**, place feet further forward to increase glute dominance. For **Bulgarian Split Squats**, position the front foot further forward and lean forward while squatting, driving through the hips. **Kickbacks** are most effective for upper glutes when kicking up and out diagonally, bracing against the machine or a bench for stability. For **Step Ups**, set the box height at or just above knee level to emphasize glutes over quads, and use a handle for balance to overload. When performing **Machine Hip Abductions**, lean forward by about 30 degrees to improve the line of pull for the upper glute fibers and achieve a deeper stretch; an extra pad can be added for more range of motion. For **Lunges** (especially walking lunges), take longer strides forward and lean slightly forward by about 30 degrees to accentuate the glute stretch. **Elevated Front Foot Lunges** involve placing the front foot on a small box for increased range of motion. **Curtsy Lunges** involve stepping back diagonally behind the other leg, which increases balance demands and glute medius activation. For **45째 Back Extensions**, round the upper back to better engage the glutes.
main_knowledge_summary.training_keys: The glutes are one of the most important and largest muscles for an impressive physique, making their development immediately noticeable. Glute training should incorporate a combination of exercises that challenge the muscles in both stretched (e.g., squats, lunges) and shortened (e.g., hip thrusts) positions for optimal growth. For **Hip Thrusts**, aim for a 5-15 rep range, focusing on progressive overload by adding weight. **Single-Leg Dumbbell Hip Thrusts** are best performed with 12-15 reps, emphasizing control to prevent muscle imbalances and engage upper glutes due to stabilization demands. **Glute Bridges** are suitable for beginners due to less stabilization required. **Frog Pumps** can serve as a high-rep finisher, targeting upper glutes through hip abduction and external rotation. **Squats** are a powerful glute builder, especially when squatting deeper (at least parallel) and focusing on hip drive. **Bulgarian Split Squats** are highly effective for a deep glute stretch and upper glute involvement but are very fatiguing; two sets per leg are often sufficient. **Donkey Kicks** and **Fire Hydrants** are primarily useful for warm-up or activation drills, not for significant hypertrophy due to low tension in the stretched position and difficulty with progressive overload. **Machine Hip Abductions** are excellent for targeting the upper glutes (medius and minimus) and can be done for 15-20 reps, though heavier low-rep work is also effective. **Lunges**, particularly walking lunges with big steps, provide a massive glute stretch and engage the entire glute, including upper glutes due to stabilization. The **Conventional Deadlift** is a good glute builder but has a low stimulus-to-fatigue ratio for glute hypertrophy, making it less ideal as a primary glute exercise. The **Sumo Deadlift** may offer slightly more upper glute emphasis due to hip abduction and external rotation. The **Romanian Deadlift (RDL)** is a superior choice for lower glute hypertrophy and the glute-hamstring tie-in, effectively smashing the glute maximus. The **45째 Back Extension** is an S-tier exercise for the entire glutes, active in both lengthened and shortened positions, and can be overloaded by adding reps or holding plates. **Cable Pull-throughs** are good for beginners but become awkward to overload with heavier weights. **Kettlebell Swings** are better for cardio and explosive power than glute hypertrophy due to insufficient tension. The video concludes that the **Walking Lunge** is the 'best of the best' glute exercise, while **Donkey Kicks** and **Fire Hydrants** are considered the 'worst' for muscle growth due to difficulty in achieving high glute tension.
main_knowledge_summary.research_insights: Multiple studies indicate that the **hip thrust** is highly effective for glute growth. A 9-week study involving untrained subjects found that the hip thrust was as effective as the squat in growing the glutes, despite the squat providing a deeper stretch. However, the video notes this is just one study, and other research suggests glutes respond well to deeper training, implying a combination of exercises challenging both stretched and shortened positions is optimal. An **EMG study** comparing conventional and Sumo deadlifts found no significant difference in glute Maximus EMG activity between the two stances, though Sumo deadlifts might emphasize the glute medius more due to wider stance and hip abduction/external rotation.
main_knowledge_summary.optimization_notes: To optimize glute training, focus on **progressive overload** by consistently increasing weight or reps. For **Hip Thrusts**, using a dedicated machine like the Nautilus Glute Drive can enhance comfort and stability, allowing for better glute engagement. For **Single-Leg Dumbbell Hip Thrusts**, prioritize control over heavy weight to prevent imbalances. **Machine Hip Abductions** can be progressed by increasing pin weight, using a gym pin for additional resistance, or adding an extra pad for increased range of motion. For **Step Ups**, holding onto a handle can improve balance, allowing for greater overload. **45째 Back Extensions** can be optimized by adding reps or holding plates to the chest. For overall muscle growth, ensure your **diet** supports your training goals by consuming the right number of calories and sufficient protein. Tools like nutrition tracking apps (e.g., MacroFactor with code Jeff) can help in dialing in dietary needs.
